highlights the need for new business models facilitating parts of the behavioural change.
has underpinned the need for an expansion of available business models to achieve universal access

. This historically weak performance of clean tech start

90 USD billion of public sector funding

Need parallel rather than sequential investment decis
The needs and gaps assessment does not
include upstream investment needs required to facilitate the technology deployment as foreseen in the
scenarios presented above. For example, for their transforming energy scenario IRENA estimates the
EVs to increase from around 8m units in 2019 to 269m units in 2030
would require investments in battery factories amounting to approximately 207 USD billion with further
investment requirements in the value chain
. This illustrates the extent of parallel
investments based on goals rather than concrete regulatory interventions and/or demand and poses a
front investment risks for each industry
in the chain in the absence of certainty of the
presence of parallel decisions in the upstream and downstream links in the chain. This is a typical
element of the valley of the death of innovation
to adoption needed for lowering the costs of systemic technical change
. Implications on risk perception, financing costs as well as investment decision making
processes and ultimately on feasibility are rarely considered.
uction of the infrastructure gap to
increase the societies resilience and the implementation of the NAPs of will require more and higher
levels of sustained financing. Activities mobilized for adaptation and resilience are often non
unding will continue coming from the public sector noted by
d, at the international level from grants based technical assistance or through budgetary support
or basket funding for large projects/program or sector wide approaches or multilateral funding under
are also anticipate supporting NAP impleme
benefits, which will include sectoral approach such as water, energy,
infrastructures, food production. According to the UNFCCC, in 2015
ance flows was supplied by multilateral climate funds, while 84 per cent came from
development finance institutions and 13 per cent from other government sources
Comprehensive reporting on adaptation finance by
argues that flows of finance for adaptation action in developing countries in 2017 and 2018 were
estimated to be approximately USD 30 billion; this plus an additional estimated flow of USD 12 billi
for dual adaptation and mitigation actions totalled USD 42 billion accounting for 7.25% of the total
estimated international public and private flows of climate finance
below the financing needs given in 15.4
To date, the private sector has limited involvement in NAPs
Those under the UNFCCC such as the GCF through its 3 million USD per country readiness and
preparatory support programme, the LDCF and the SCCF a
nd the PPCR and ASAP are focused on supporting the
preparatory process of the NAPs. But the Adaptation Fund will support the implementation of concrete projects
up to 10 million USD per country.
